Dear Ms. Stenzel:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
10/31/2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
MCL 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of conditions,
books, records, and reports; access by department, bureau
of fire services, or local authorities; records; report; forms;
confidentiality; disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be provided
to department; failure of licensee to cooperate with
investigation, inspection, or examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care and
shall report to the department, when requested, the facts
the department requires with reference to the children upon
forms furnished by the department. Except as otherwise
provided in this subsection and subsection (4), records
regarding children and facts compiled about children and
their parents and relatives are confidential and disclosure
of this information shall be properly safeguarded by the
childcare organization, the department, and any other entity
in possession of the information. Records that are
confidential under this section are available to both of the
following:

compliance:
 Two of the five special evaluations documented the
birthmother or birth parents name in the evaluation.
 Four of the five special evaluations documented CPS

R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following

(d) Three references obtained from persons who are unrelated

CI-16-182a Communication Issuance. Security Awareness Training for
Fingerprint Base Criminal History Requirements
Security Awareness Training (SAT) is required for authorized
personnel who have been granted access to fingerprint-based
Criminal History Record Information (CHRI). This training
provides information on what fingerprint based CHRI is, who
has access, how to ensure this information remains secure both
physically an electronically, and how you can use this
information appropriately.
All non-contracted and governmental CPA employees,
subcontractors, subcontractor’s employees or volunteers who
are authorized to have access to fingerprint based CHRI must
successfully complete SAT within six months of appointment to
a position with CHRI access and every two years thereafter.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There were one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The incident related to an allegation that after the foster parents’ son, swung a
shovel at her several times, the son then went inside and pulled a foster child by the
feet off the couch, causing pain in the foster child’s back. During the investigation
the foster parent admitted she hit her son on the back of the head with a hot sauce
bottle in attempt to get him to let go of the foster child’s feet. The foster parent was
found in violation of the behavior management rule and a corrective action plan was
completed.
The agency followed departmental timeframes related to this incident and its actions
with the foster parent appeared appropriate. The agency received a citation under,
MCL 722.120(3) and R400.12327(6)(b) as cited in this report.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
That corrective plan related to the agency’s 2018 Interim Inspection. During that
inspection the agency received one Act 116 citation, twenty-four rule violations,
three ISEP citations, eight policy violations; and one communication issuance
citation. The agency was not successful with the corrective plan related that
inspection as the agency received a number of repeat violations, as documented in
this report.
It is noteworthy the agency has experienced a number of employee changes. It has
a new licensing supervisor, two new licensing workers and four new foster care
workers.
DCWL ANALYST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
There were no foster home safety alerts.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
